awd_titl_txt: RAPID: The Dynamics of Minority Support for the Supreme Court.
awd_abstract_narration:
Public trust in the Supreme Court is vital for the health of American democracy. Recent controversies, however, have brought unprecedented challenges to the Court’s legitimacy. With trust in the Court at historic lows and recent research suggesting the Court’s legitimacy may be more fragile than previously thought, commentators and scholars alike are raising increasingly dire warnings that the Court’s decisions in highly salient cases have the potential to erode its foundation of public support. Largely missing from this growing discussion of the Court’s public standing, however, is the perspective of the country’s racial and ethnic minorities. As a result, it is unclear whether minority citizens continue to hold the Court in high regard and what impact, if any, the Court’s decisions have on that support. 

To explore the dynamics of support for the Supreme Court among minority citizens, the project will employ a combination of survey research and elite interviews. A nationally-representative survey of Americans will provide insights into the state of public support for the Supreme Court, with an oversampling of African-American, Hispanic, and Native American respondents allowing for detailed analyses of the Court’s standing among minority citizens. To understand the effect of a significant Court decision on minority citizens’ views of the Court, the project will further focus on the attitudes of Native Americans. To do so, the project will leverage the Court’s anticipated 2023 ruling in a high-profile case in two ways. First, Native American survey respondents will be re-contacted after the Court’s decision with a second wave of the survey, thereby providing an opportunity to evaluate the impact of the ruling on the Court’s support among those most directly affected by the decision. Second, interviews with leaders of Native American tribes both before and after the Court’s decision will grant insights into the ruling’s impact on the views of minority communities’ political leaders. The findings from this research will yield important insights into the Supreme Court’s relationship with minorities at this critical juncture in American politics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Public trust in the Supreme Court is vital for the health of American democracy. Recent controversies, however, have brought unprecedented challenges to the Court’s legitimacy. With trust in the Court at historic lows and recent research suggesting the Court’s legitimacy may be more fragile than previously thought, commentators and scholars alike are raising increasingly dire warnings that the Court’s decisions in highly salient cases have the potential to erode its foundation of public support. Largely missing from this discussion of the Court’s public standing, however, is the perspective of the country’s racial and ethnic minorities. As a result, it is unclear to what extent minority citizens hold the Court in high regard and what impact, if any, the Court’s decisions have on that support.

This project combined survey research with elite interviews to explore the dynamics of support for the Supreme Court among America’s understudied minority populations, with a particular focus on the views of Native Americans. To do so, the project leveraged the Court’s issuance in June 2023 of highly salient decisions, particularly one regarding Native American rights, using a panel survey with waves fielded in the months prior to and after the rulings. Interviews with political leaders and judges from six different Native American tribes further supplemented the survey data to investigate attitudes toward the Court and the American legal system in general. Initial results suggest that minority citizens hold distinct views of the Court, with concerns over tribal sovereignty figuring prominently in Native Americans’ assessments. Moreover, the data indicate a high level of awareness and interest in the Supreme Court’s decision making among Native Americans, particularly in cases that directly affect tribal sovereignty. Experimental data go on to demonstrate the dynamics of Native Americans’ support for the Supreme Court, particularly with respect to the Court’s jurisprudence on Native American rights and when contrasted to tribal courts.

The study advances existing knowledge in four important respects. First, the project’s survey data provides unique insights into judicial legitimacy among understudied minorities. In particular, the project provides a rare dataset on the political attitudes of Native Americans, a group that has been largely overlooked in much of the extant literature. Second, the survey’s panel structure facilitates the study of changes in these attitudes toward the Court in the shadow of salient decisions, thus allowing the project to contribute to the scholarly debate on the stability and evolution of judicial legitimacy. Third, the project’s interview data enables the inclusion of Native American leaders’ voices in the study of the Supreme Court’s public standing. Fourth, the project expands existing research by providing a first of its kind engagement with public sentiment toward tribal courts both in their own right and in comparison with other judicial institutions.

The broader impacts of the project spanned academic, teaching, and public-facing activities. In addition to presentations of findings at academic venues, multiple article-length manuscripts are either in preparation or submitted to peer-reviewed journals. A proposal centered on the findings regarding Native Americans further represents the initial stages of a book project. Aspects of the project, including survey design and research ethics, enriched graduate-level research design courses and provided opportunities to involve PhD students in the research process. Furthermore, travel to conduct interviews facilitated the project’s direct engagement with Native American communities and the potential to disseminate data and findings to those communities, including tribal colleges and universities.
